headline: World breaks hottest day record twice in a week
context: The record for the world's hottest day has tumbled twice in one week, according to the European climate change service.
On Monday the global average surface air temperature reached 17.15C, breaking the record of 17.09C set on Sunday.

annotations.paragraph: It beats the record set in July 2023, and it could break again this week.
annotations.reason: Provides context on the frequency of record-breaking temperatures.

annotations.paragraph: Parts of the world are experiencing powerful heatwaves including the Mediterranean, Russia and Canada.
annotations.reason: Gives specific examples of regions affected by heatwaves.

annotations.paragraph: Climate change is driving up global temperatures as greenhouse gas emissions released when humans burn fossil fuels warm the Earth's atmosphere.
annotations.reason: Explains the underlying cause of rising global temperatures.

annotations.paragraph: "While fluctuations are to be expected, as the climate continues to warm, we are likely to keep seeing records being broken, and each new record is taking us further into uncharted territory," says Prof Rebecca Emerton, a climate scientist at the Copernicus Climate Change Service.
annotations.reason: Provides expert commentary on the implications of the record-breaking temperatures.

annotations.paragraph: The naturally-occurring climate phenomenon El Niño also added heat to the climate in the first six months of this year but its effects have now waned.
annotations.reason: Offers additional context on factors contributing to temperature changes.

annotations.paragraph: Extreme heat is a serious health hazard, with thousands of deaths attributed to high temperatures every year.

annotations.paragraph: The global average temperature usually peaks in July or August during summer in the northern hemisphere.

annotations.paragraph: The recent sudden rise in temperatures is also down to significantly-above-average temperatures over large parts of Antarctica, according to Prof Emerton.

annotations.paragraph: Large swings in temperature are not unusual in Antarctica at this time of year - they also contributed to record temperatures in 2023.

annotations.paragraph: Sea ice in the region is almost as low as this time last year, which also leads to above-average sea temperatures in the Southern Ocean.
annotations.reason: Explains a contributing factor to the temperature rise, relevant to the record-breaking event.

annotations.paragraph: “The hottest day record has been broken once again because the world continues to burn huge amounts of oil, gas, and coal," says Friederike Otto, Senior Lecturer in Climate Science at Grantham Institute at Imperial College London.
annotations.reason: Provides expert commentary linking the record to fossil fuel consumption.

annotations.paragraph: “Every broken record is a warning that our climate is heating to dangerous levels. These warnings are becoming much more frequent; however, we have all the tools, technology and knowledge to stop things from getting worse – replace fossil fuels with renewable energy and get emissions down to net zero as quickly as possible," she added.
